abstracts.cdata!:
The original project design was both
            ambitious and risky. While the project contributed
            significantly to increasing Peru's capacity to forecast
            and respond to future El Nino events, it only achieved
            partial restoration of assets originally targeted within the
            project period, and about 55 percent of the laon amount had
            to be cancelled. On balance, therefore, the project outcome
            is rated unsatisfactory. Overall, project sustainabiliy is
            rated likely: Many works which by their nature were
            temporary mitigated the impact of the El Nino phenomenon.
            The sustainability of the institutional development
            achievements for future disaster forecasting will depend on
            continuing cooperation among the agencies under the Estudio
            Nacional del Fenomeno "El Nino" (ENFEN), whether
            budgetary resources continue to be available to these
            agencies, and their ability to develop and retain qualified
            professionals. While the project was large and necessarily
            undefined at appraisal which posed risks for implementation,
            and there were insufficient safeguards for reassessing the
            project and its scope after the impact of the disaster was
            known, the Bank did respond quickly and flexibly to the
            emergency. During supervision it correctly identified the
            need to reassess and reduce the project, particularly the
            roads component. Also, the Bank successfully supervised the
            works and designs as well as the institutionsl development
            components. Borrower performance was marginally satisfactory.
